Talon:

talon ate the fish and looked athe paint and said "Do they think th=
at you are actually a sort of deity as well as the other one?"

--- In nbwr=
pg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico <magicquartz@...> wrote:
>
> Tucson embra=
ces Talon with his tail around her shoulders.
> 
> " So will I. Talon, so w=
ill I.  But that doesn't mean we can't try to recreate a little portion of =
life on our own planet.  This seed we were given, it needs soil, water, lig=
ht and something to plant it in.  Perhaps we can find a place where there i=
s an abundance of soil and take that with us. "
> 
> Just as he spoke, a Pr=
otohuman, carrying an offering of fish, kneels down before Tucson and Talon=
.  Tucson looks to the offering.  It was a most generous portion of fish.  =
Yet now he could not eat it, but he knew Talon would need nourishment.  He =
nods gently to the Protohuman and accepts his offering with a gentile touch=
 of his nose on the man's shoulder.  He allows him to stroke his snout as s=
ome sort of good luck ritual.  The man bows in graciousness to Tucson's ges=
ture of kindness and leaves him be with Talon.
> 
> " I'm not so sure what =
all of that meant but, whatever it was, it was a very kind  gesture on his =
part.  I wonder if these people had any interaction with the old Silver Dra=
gon.. " 
> 
> It isn't long before others come to offer more gifts to him a=
nd Talon.  One of the Protohumans points to a painting on a rock, with whit=
e portraying silver, in a primitive image of a large reptile with outstretc=
hed wings.
> 
> " Oh, I see now..  Yes, they have seen him before.  To them=
 he is a guardian, and the more offerings they gave him, he would return th=
eir kind gestures by offering his protection.  But there is more to these p=
aintings..  A strange mysterious figure, with an aura around it..  To me it=
 seems evil.  Another idol, someone else to worship. ..  People portrayed i=
n black and white..  White, meaning those who look to the Silver Dragon and=
 black to those who worship the intimidating idol..  I've seen ancient pict=
ographs before on Cybertron, and these are different but in the same format=
. Talon if the dragon is a physical being, then this dark idol must be as w=
ell.  We need to find it, before it lays harm to anyone."
>

 who specializes in illustration, using traditional and digital media.

eed a great gift idea that is original?  No problem!  Email me at this addr=
ess and we will talk.

ings and said softly "I will miss all this"
> > 
> > --- In nbwrpg@yahoogro=
ups.com, Sandra Panico <magicquartz@> wrote:
> > >
> > > With a gentile smi=
le, Tucson returns the kiss and holds his wing over them to provide a momen=
t alone with Talon. After the kiss he lowers his wing and notices that a co=
llection of small creatures surrounding him and Talon . Yet they do so in a=
 fashion of admiration rather than hostility. Tucson looks to them curiousl=
y.
> > > 
> > > " I'm not sure why these creatures are curious about us but=
 it appears as if they're here to admire rather than attack. I wonder... "
=
> > > 
> > > He stands up and gets back into beast mode, and sits down once=
 more. The creatures draw closer to him and sit beside him and Talon. It wa=
s clear that the Silver Dragon was a source of comfort to these creatures, =
but that was about to change once he and Talon left for Cybertron. It was a=
 massive guilt slammed upon his heart. Yet how could he get the animals to =
understand that he had to leave them in such a short time? He was now their=
 guardian and they were looking up to him for protection. 
> > > 
> > > " T=
alon, these creatures remember the old dragon that sought to their protecti=
on and realize that I have taken his place. It's as I thought, they aren't =
aware of who we really are, and where we are from. They will not understand=
 that we must leave them shortly, for good, and Primus knows what will happ=
en to them once we leave. ... Talon, I hear something coming. It's not a Pr=
edacon but it's a fairly large creature."
> > > 
> > > Not far from them, T=
ucson spots the scales of a rather large reptile, that appears to be fishin=
g in the stream next to them. He watches attentively and at that moment, th=
e creature lifts its head. It was another dragon. Yet this one was a bit sm=
aller than he was, but the same coloration. He takes note of its slender sh=
ape. It was female. She looks to him as he looks to her. She slowly approac=
hes him and they look gently to each other like brother and sister. In drac=
onic vocalization, Tucson explains who he is and his dilemma.  She intern r=
umbles back and bows her head. She nods as he does. It was their way of com=
municating as Tucson looks back to Talon.
> > > 
> > > " Apparently the old=
 dragon has family here. They are scattered but they exist. And she said th=
at she will protect these creatures and this land along with her brethren f=
or as long as they live. And she wishes us good luck on our journey."
> > >=
 
> > > With that, the dragoness leaves them peacefully to enjoy their time=
 together. With a gentile groan, the creatures too, depart. It was truly a =
spiritual moment for both of them.

> --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico <magicquartz@> wrote:
> > > =
> >
> > > > > Tucson holds Talon gently with an arm around her shoulders. H=
e looks up and then back to her.
> > > > > 
> > > > > " Like a branch on a =
tree that has broken off during a storm and regrows in a different directio=
n than it had been, before it had broken off. I know exactly how you feel. =
I feel the same way. At one time, I was blind, rolled on four wheels and I =
always seemed to be an Autobot rebel. I fought along side with my comrades =
but I wasn't good at following orders. I was well grounded but lost at the =
same time. Then, I met you and things began to change on a more positive no=
te. You may not believe this, but you helped me to find my path, and you sa=
w me on the right road and guided me to my true fate. Soon afterwards, I be=
came a Prime, acquired seventeen more wheels, and almost looked like Optimu=
s Prime, yet different. But one thing didn't change, I was still battling b=
lindness off and on. Then, a third change, due to extensive damage to my pr=
evious form, which could not be repaired, I was guided to my final evolutio=
n, this one. All of these things wouldn't have come about if I had never me=
t you. And I wouldn't have it any other way. Talon, I will miss this planet=
 as much as you are, and hopefully we can tell our offspring all about this=
 planet and it's wondrous varieties of life that live here."
> > > > > 
> >=
 > > > The rodent climbs down and drops a nut into his hand, and chatters t=
o him.
> > > > > 
> > > > > " This is for us to keep? Thank you, we will ta=
ke good care of it."
> > > > > 
> > > > > He places the nut in Talon's hand=
.
> > > > > 
> > > > > " I think we have a way to bring back a small remind=
er of this planet. Let's see if we can encourage it to grow on ours."

> > >
> > > > > > > > > With a happy look on his face, Tucson walks with Ta=
lon, down the corridor and out to a walking trail which he had been down be=
fore but could not see. It was leading to the old dragon's cave. But the pa=
th itself carries a serene atmosphere as a gentile stream ripples over glis=
tening river rocks while dragonflies dodge the current of the water. And no=
w, for the first time, Tucson could actually enjoy it visually as well as h=
armonically. 
> > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > " I've been this way onc=
e before, but I wanted to return here when it was possible for both of us t=
o enjoy it together. And now, we can. I can see why Leo is concerned, so mu=
ch innocent life, too valuable to destroy. The entire planet is a treasure =
within itself. And who better to enjoy this treasure than with you? No one.=
 I only hope that after we leave, this world will remain as pure as it is n=
ow. But there's more that I want to show you."
> > > > > > > > > 
> > > > >=
 > > > > He takes Talon into a forest of giant trees and points upward.
> >=
 > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > " If you sit under this tree and look str=
aight up, it appears to be reaching to the sky, yet it shades you from the =
heat of the sun. It provides shelter and protection, yet it does so in an i=
nnocent manner. It's something Master Yoketron taught me, when he was my Se=
nsai. See things with a different perspective and not always what everyone =
else sees. Here, I'll show you. "
> > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > He s=
hows Talon to a boulder beneath a large hardwood tree and sits right under =
it,looking up.
> > > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > > " If you sit right here=
 beside me and look up, you'll see what I mean."
